page.lettertext:
fol.194r
1591 19 August To my L. Trea
s
Belgia: 1591: Au
g
May it please yo
r
good L. I have used toward
Count Maurice
those gratulatory complement
, w
ch
her
Hig
nes
hath required,
by yo
r
L. l
re
of
e 25
th
of
e last w
ch
Rxd at
Arnham
the 22 of this p
nt
, & there presented that letter w
ch
her Ma
ty
writ unto him. Hee accepted it of mee very cheerfully
as a singular token of her gratious favour, & so hee
protested w
th
his humblest thank
, & w
th
e offer of his
s
vice
in all occasyons whatsoever. Because his letter heerw
th
is an answere therunto, I refer my self to
t
w
ch
he himself
hath signified. To
e same effect, as yo
r
L. hath
written in favo
r
of
M
r
Winter
, both
Sir Francis Vere
, & I
were in hand w
th
e Count,
e next daie after
t
e ennemy
was defeated. And as he
mised th
e
very willingly
so now again hee assured mee, that M
r
Winter shall have
any one or two of those prisoners, as he himself wil desire
& that none shalbee redeemed, till some order hath bin taken
of his ransome. Alwaies provided, that consyderation may
bee had, for contenting
e Captaines, by whom these prisoners
were taken. There are but 3 of th
e
remayning. The
rest are all delivered. But these are
e chiefest, & yet I
dout
e Spaniard
will not give M
r
Winter for them all.
Heer ys
Alfonso d'avaolos
bastard broth
r
to
e
Marquis of Guasto
who for ought wee can heare, hath but a pensyon of 1000
li
by
e yeare, & his company of horse. Hee ys prisoner to
one
Captaine Kintscey
. The second is
Pedro Francesco de
Nicelli
, who is prisoner to Captaine
Bax
&
Ball.
We cannot
und
r
stand
t
he hath any staie of Living, besides the benefit
of
e cornet, wherof he was captaine w
ch
was gard unto
e
Duke
& happely some pay, for being g
na
l commander of
e horsmen by
provision. The third is
Count Decio
, who is prisoner to
S
r
John Pooly
, be a young
r
broth
r
of those count
of Italy & as
it is thought & affirmed by him self hath nothing of his owne,
but
e bare entertaynm
e
t of a Lieuten
a
t to
Jeronimo Carraffa.
The welthiest among th
e
all was on
Pradilio,
who died in Arnham
of his wound
. In effect I have told M
r
Winters servant
that whatsoev
r
usage w
th
reason of those that are in custody
may stand his M
r
in steed, for his speedier deliverance
I do not dout but
e Count will willingly yeld unto yt
And I will signify as much to
e prisoners th
e
selves
& get theyr l
re
s to
Montdragon,
to cause M
r
Winter to be
better entreated. Wheras yo
r
L. doth require a
description of
e places, where any service is
fourmed, it is not
possible many times, but by naming of such places as are
adjoyning; w
ch
I thought I had alwaies set downe sufficiently
For heer are many fort
in these countreys, aswell of
e ennemy
fol.194v
Belgia: 1591: Au
g
as of o
rs
, & in
Groning
e
espetially, that have bin made but of
late, & are not expressed in any cart of
t
Countrey. And likewise
for
e platts of ground
& formes of fightes, of w
ch
yo
r
L. is desirous
unles it were so
t
e
Councel
were p
nt
in
e place of conflict
it cannot be don very readely. for though
e Councel of state
bee often at
e Campe, yet their usuall resydence, is at
e next
& safest towne; & there they are informed, how any action doth passe
w
ch
is but sommarely, & by l
re
s on
e suddain, w
ch
I do c
r
tifye
p
nt
ly in as ample sort as
e Intelligence is given, And if I should
attend
e retourne of some Captaine, to describe every circumstance
it would require a leisure time, & hind
r
her Hig
nes
from speedy
advertisement./ There are some men heer sometimes that do
po
r
trait such
s
vices, of w
ch
I will not faile to send you any
t
can be gotten
of o
r
latter exploit
& for mine owne
te heerafter to use all
endevours, for expressing all thing
more
ticularely. Moreover in
any encounter or miltary action, that either on nation above other, or
spetiall
sons above
e rest, shall shew any valleur to be noted a
te
I will not faile to report it, as theyr
s
vice shall merit. But in
e
late defeat of
e Ennemies horse, the most of o
r
troupes aswell of
horsem
e
as footmen consisted of squadrons & devided companies, & no
mans endevo
r
was much more eminent then other. And as for
leaders in
e field & principall officers, there are scarcely any in
the states Army, but such as Co. Maurice doth depute for
e time. Onely
Mons
r
de Faima
hath a
manent office, being g
na
l of
e Artillery
& oth
r
wise a gentleman of singula
r
experience. Heer is also
Mons
r
de Grise
commissary g
na
l of
e vittuales. But no mans advise is
more respected & followed then
S
r
Francis Veres
, who is commonly used
by
e Count as Mareschall of
e field, & doth content
e countrey
exceedingly, for his carefulnes in all thing
, aswell for direction as
execution. Being come but newly to
e Hage, where
e
councel of state is retourned againe, I have spoken w
th
Matruit
the states commissary upon whom
S
r
Edward Norreis
doth rely for making
answere in his behalf to all theyr imputations. I know
e
ty
very well to be a man of very good discretion, & I know his
affection to o
r
nation in generall, & to S
r
Edward in
ticula
r
, to be
more then ordinary. for w
ch
I see not how
e gouverno
r
could have
sent a fitter for his purpose: albeit hee was sent for by
e
states
of Zeland
, upon occasyon of oth
r
buisines. It is
force in thos
affaires, that I must be plainer, tho' I would bee willingly, if
her Ma
ty
mighte be oth
r
wise effectually
s
ved. The forsaid
commissary hath bin one of
e chiefest, that hath from time to time
informed this Councel of those abuses of
e Governo
r
, being bound
therunto by his office & other, & not concealing from
e Governo
r
his
ceeding so roundly. Nevertheles though he delt
in that
order for discharge of his duty, I finde him very
ready to
fol.195r
Belgia: 1591: Au
g
accompany his complaint
w
th
his best construction & to do
any good office, to make a quiet composition betweene the
states &
e Governo
r
. But his travell therin cannot
greatly steed
e [governo
r
]. For
e states are
swaded
that all his letters & offers to her Ma
ty
, & to them are
but meere excuses & cuning devises, tending to no other
but to winne a litel time; w
ch
bring
a great deal of
gaine in those exactions, & profit
that hee reapeth
continually by usurpation up
o
e countrey. for at this
very p
nt
they have intelligence from
Ostend,
that those
of
Bridges
have p
nt
ed him w
th
12 silver cuppes
w
ch
he hath receaved for
e confirmation of theyr entercowrse.
And this is certified hether, w
th
an other long list of
neer accusations. I cannot say upon certainty, that every
thing is trew, that hath bin heer to fore, or is now imputed
unto him (albeit I cannot yet in any thing convince the
informers of a wrong report) but of this I am assured
that
e greatest point
of importance are very manifest & trew
of those
t
were comprised in this Councels l
re
to her Hig
nes
.
More over there is a fresher accusation, then any of theyr former
that is newly sent heth
r
from the States of Zeland, to
e g
na
l
states, but not im
ted as yet to
e Councel of State, for w
ch
I cannot yet certifie, what is written in
ticular, but in g
na
l
I heare, that
e states of Zeland und
r
standing
t
one
Peeter
Cortiken
Greffier du Franc, w
ch
is one of
e 4 members of
Flandres
had spetiall accesse & conference in secret w
th
e
governo
r
of Ostend, & from him had recowrse to
e
D. of Parma
going often in & out w
th
great offence to all
e Countrey, to know
what practise was in hand, laid wait for
e said Cortiken
tooke him prisoner upon
e waie, & brought him to
Midelbourgh
where they finde by his confession, that his treaty w
th
e Governo
r
was to contrive a peace between her Ma
ty
&
e ennemy, the
Governo
r
und
r
taking to
suade w
th
her Hig
nes
, &
e Greffier
mising to worke
e Duke there unto, & this they saie hee hath
declared w
th
very spetiall circumstance, w
ch
when it comes
unto my hand
I will send unto yo
r
L. Howsoev
r
this matter
hath bin handled by
e Governo
r
, I see it doth distem
this
people not a litell. All that I do feare is least
e troublesome
fire of theyr wonted Jalousies & diffidences, w
ch
was never
quenched thorowly, albeit now of late it was not much to bee
ceaved will kindle now a freshe, & cause her Ma
t
s
vaunt
that are heer in these countreys to become more unprofitable
then they might be otherwise. For I am almoste out of hope
that they will ever keep any
fect correspondence w
th
those they
dare not trust. I know this matt
r
ere be long wilbee bitterly
proposed, & what answere I should make I am altogeth
r
doutfull
fol.195v
Belgia: 1591: Au
g
being ignorant as I am, how
e governo
r
hath proceeded
& w
th
what intelligence from home. But for mee, there shalbee
nothing heer omitted, wherby any over sight, therewith hee may be
charged, may be either colourd, or excused, or construed to e best
for many important causes as of late I have written in a letter
to yo
r
L. so now againe I am to signify, that for the good
conduction of these affaires of her Hig
nes
, there is nothing more
expedient, th
e
that such as are heer of her Ma
t
ministers, should
im
te their dealing in some degree w
th
him that is heer as her
Hig
nes
Councello
r
, for in all such occasyons, as are offred now
it is commonly to mee
t
they addresse theyr first complaint
& what
credit I can have to seem to know nothing, or to heare that I
would not & yet be fored to excuse it, I leave to yo
r
L. to
consider, where I certified yo
r
L. that
e states of Zeland were
resolved to take some course among themselves, to redresse those
disorders committed by
e governo
r
I do learne by Matruit, that they
were once determined (though hee know not at this p
nt
how they
are disposed, to prohibit
e cariage of any vittailes to Ostende
w
th
out
e payeng of licence mony, w
ch
is onely paid for vittailes
to
e ennemy, And that in regard, that
e Governo
r
him self doth
traffique & send those vittailes to
e ennemy that come out of
Zeland. As yo
r
L. doth signify
e states of Zeland have
bin earnestly bent, to decay
e contributions of
e countrey of Flandres
But it is ordayned by
e g
na
l states that they shalbee c
o
tinued
w
th
sufficient provisoes to meet w
th
all inconveniences that those of
Zeland can p
r
tend. In
t
yo
r
L. doth suppose
t
Holl
a
d &
Zeland are but coldly inclined, to extend theyr bond
in Flandres
I can assure yo
u
t
the enterprise intended upon
e Land of Waes
wh
r
of I made mention in my Last fr
o
Arnham,
is at
e spetiall
motion of those of Zeland, And they would willingly of
em selves
that
e provinces would concurr to assaile
e ennemy in those quarters
But they of
Frise,
Gelders
&
Overissel,
& likewise
Utrecht,
have bin
alwaies very vehement in opposing against yt, refusing flatly to send
any forces so farr from theyr Provinces, wh
r
by the ennemy might be
moved to take
em un
vided. for though they know
t
in Flanders,
e
losse of any place of good acchount might annoy
e ennemy very
mig htely, yet they think on
e oth
r
side
t
e assurance of theyr
state, &
e custody of
t
w
ch
they have in possession is more to be
respected, th
e
e adding more unto yt by taking fr
o
the Ennemy.
Now
t
Devent
r
&
Zutph
e
are recovered againe, if
Nieumeg
e
might
be gotten,
e most
te of these contreys shold stand in good security
& ther could be no excuse for not employeng theyr forces to
e joining
of oth
r
places. The Ennemy wee do heare is still in those
part
w
ch
I mentioned laste unto yo
u
, but
e brute is very
constant of his going for
France,
w
ch
is also confirmed by l
re
s
from
Brussels
from wherin they write that
e states have condisce
nded
to raise 2 regiment
upon theyr owne pro
charges, to defend
e
contrey
in
e absence of
e Duke. Count Maurice hath l
re
s this
day
t
fol.196r
Belgia 1591 19 Au
g
To my L. Trea
s
Belgia: 1591: Au
g
the Duke is gon to
Namurs,
&
t
e Princes of
Germany
have
taken such order in theyr severall territories, as his levies of
horse will hardly get unto him. S
r
Francis Vere is appointed
w
th
some 10 or 11 cornet
of horse to marche toward
Linghen
by
e County of Benthem to spoile
e countrey people, & as
avantages are offered, to deal w
th
those troupes of
e ennemy that
lie scattered in those quarters. There be divers difficultyes
moved in
e enterprise of
Hulst,
w
ch
require good information before
the action bee attempted, To that effect there are men employed
& wee expect every houre what word they will bring, w
ch
I will
signify to yo
r
L. w
th
e first opportunity
& so I take my humble
leave. Hage. Au
g
19 1591.
